subject: Data
title: Distorted Proportions: Area and Volume Tricks
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Distorted Proportions: Area and Volume Tricks.

hook.text: A chart doubles the height of a money bag icon to show 'doubled spending.' But the visual area quadruples.

buildup.text: When you scale a 2D icon by height, its area grows by the square. A 3D icon grows by the cube.

discovery.text: Our eyes perceive area, not height. So doubling height makes something look four times larger.

twist.text: Infographics use this trick constantly â€” especially with bubble charts, pictograms, and icon arrays.

climax.text: The fix is simple: scale by area, not height. But most chart creators don't know the difference.

punchline.text: Double the height, quadruple the lie.

quiz.question: When you double the height of a 2D icon, by how much does its visual area increase?
